update.description:
Sample deployment of a team of Jackal, Husky, and Iris into a cave environment

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/3594140239-example.jpg)
![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/418104792-Peek%202018-08-14%2015-53-2.gif)
‌

`team.launch` spawns a team of Jackal, Husky, and Iris, equipped with lights. A user can control them by either a gamepad or keyboard. The designs of the lights and dispositions are just for demonstration and to be redesigned.

**URDF**

* Added `urdf/xacro` files for flashlight and LED models \(in `subt_gazebo`\)
* Added `husky_equipments.urdf.xacro`, `jackal_equipments.urdf.xacro`, `iris_equipments.urdf.xacro` defining how a robot holds the lights
* Added revised versions of `husky.urdf.xacro` and `jackal.urdf.xacro`, so as to include the files above and to deploy multiple robots.

**Updated subt\_example\_node**

It has the following features now.

* Teleop: listens to topics advertised by joy stick/keyboard teleop
* Communication: uses CommsClient to send a message to another robot. Both sender and receivers flash their center LED.
* Flashlights: publishes ROS messages to control its flashlights.
* Control of a robot: publishes ROS message to each robot `cmd_vel` topic
* Selection: while being selected by the teleop, it blinks its left and right LEDs.

**Teleop by the keyboard**

Type:  
 `rosrun subt_example teleop_twist_keyboard.py`

It is almost the same as the original teleop script, but it displays a list of robots and you can choose a robot to control by hitting the corresponding number keys \(1-9 and 0\). The keys `a` and `s` turn the lights on and off, respectively. The script loads a yaml file `config/robot_config.yaml` containing a list of robot names. When you hit a number key while pressing down a shift key, the currently selected robot sends a message to the robot with the corresponding number.

**Teleop by the \(logitech\) joy stick**

Config data is in `config/logitech_config.yaml`

* To move robots: hold the left button \(LB\) and use the left joy stick to go forward/backward and turn.
* To use the turbo mode: hold the right button \(RB\) and use the same joy stick.
* For Iris, use the right joy stick to move vertically \(z-axis\) and horizontally \(y-axis\).
* To turn the lights on/off: use the left trigger \(LT\) / right trigger \(RT\).
* To select the robot: press A, B, X, or Y button \(the key bindings are defined in `config/robot_config.yaml`\).
* To send a message: press an arrow key

**lava\_tube.world**

To make the environment to look more realistic \(and just for fun\)

* Removed the sun
* Added the color of the cave in model.sdf
update.title: Teleop of a team of Jackal, Husky, and Iris (in a dark lava tube)

pull_request.title: Teleop of a team of Jackal, Husky, and Iris (in a dark lava tube)

pullrequest.title: Teleop of a team of Jackal, Husky, and Iris (in a dark lava tube)

content.raw:
As for Husky, its `description.launch` accepts extra urdf files but does not maintain robot’s name space and, if more than one Husky is spawn, all of them would have the same topic names in default. There is an option about “multimaster bringup”. I am not sure if it could provide separate name spaces, but I will take a look.

**Update:** As I tried to use "multimaster" we need a package `multimaster_launch`, which is not available for melodic now. Plus, still don’t know if this package could provide distinct topic names. At the moment, I think we need custom launch files…
content.html:
As for Husky, its description.launch accepts extra urdf files but does not maintain robot’s name space and, if more than one Husky is spawn, all of them would have the same topic names in default. There is an option about “multimaster bringup”. I am not sure if it could provide separate name spaces, but I will take a look.

Update: As I tried to use "multimaster" we need a package multimaster_launch, which is not available for melodic now. Plus, still don’t know if this package could provide distinct topic names. At the moment, I think we need custom launch files…

pull_request.title: Teleop of a team of Jackal, Husky, and Iris (in a dark lava tube)

pullrequest.title: Teleop of a team of Jackal, Husky, and Iris (in a dark lava tube)

content.raw:
Apparently, xacro's macro accepts an empty block parameter but still needs an empty block like `<params></params>`. I updated the xacro files as the default settings \(constant white light\) are overwritten when the block parameter has some values.

[#!/osrf/subt/commits/99014ea426db8d183a4b162305873edff6686e61?at=default](#!/osrf/subt/commits/99014ea426db8d183a4b162305873edff6686e61?at=default)
content.html:
Apparently, xacro's macro accepts an empty block parameter but still needs an empty block like <params></params>. I updated the xacro files as the default settings (constant white light) are overwritten when the block parameter has some values.

#!/osrf/subt/commits/99014ea426db8d183a4b162305873edff6686e61?at=default

pull_request.title: Teleop of a team of Jackal, Husky, and Iris (in a dark lava tube)

update.description:
Sample deployment of Husky/Jackal team into a cave environment

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/2224798273-pic.jpg)
‌

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/2295761883-Peek%202018-07-31%2011-45.gif)
‌

`husky_team.launch` and `jackal_team.launch` spawn teams of Huskies and Jackals respectively, in addition to one Iris quadcopter. The designs of the lights and dispositions are just for demonstration and to be redesigned.

**URDF**

* Added `urdf/xacro` files for flashlight and LED models \(in `subt_gazebo`\)
* Added `husky_equipments.urdf.xacro`, `jackal_equipments.urdf.xacro`, `iris_equipments.urdf.xacro` defining how a robot holds the lights
* Added revised versions of `husky.urdf.xacro` and `jackal.urdf.xacro`, so as to include the files above and to deploy multiple robots.

**Updated subt\_example\_node**

It has the following features now.

* Teleop: listens to topics advertised by joy stick/keyboard teleop
* Communication: uses CommsClient to send a message to another robot. Both sender and receivers flash their center LED.
* Flashlights: publishes ROS messages to control its flashlights.
* Control of a robot: publishes ROS message to each robot `cmd_vel` topic
* Selection: while being selected by the teleop, it blinks its left and right LEDs.

**Teleop by the keyboard**

Type:  
 `rosrun subt_example teleop_twist_keyboard.py`

It is almost the same as the original teleop script, but it displays a list of robots and you can choose a robot to control by hitting the corresponding number keys \(1-9 and 0\). The keys `a` and `s` turn the lights on and off, respectively. The script loads a yaml file `config/robot_config.yaml` containing a list of robot names. When you hit a number key while pressing down a shift key, the currently selected robot sends a message to the robot with the corresponding number.

**Teleop by the \(logitech\) joy stick**

Config data is in `config/logitech_config.yaml`

* To move robots: hold the left button \(LB\) and use the left joy stick to go forward/backward and turn.
* To use the turbo mode: hold the right button \(RB\) and use the same joy stick.
* For Iris, use the right joy stick to move vertically \(z-axis\) and horizontally \(y-axis\).
* To turn the lights on/off: use the left trigger \(LT\) / right trigger \(RT\).
* To select the robot: press A, B, X, or Y button \(the key bindings are defined in `config/robot_config.yaml`\).
* To send a message: press an arrow key

**lava\_tube.world**

To make the environment to look more realistic \(and just for fun\)

* Removed the sun
* Added the color of the cave in model.sdf
update.title: Multiple Huskies/Jackals + Iris (in a dark lava tube)

content.raw:
I remember about Jackal that its `description.launch` does not accept urdf models \(i.e., flashlight and LED\) from outside of the package. I think it is the same reason for Husky, but I will double-check it.

Maybe, there is another way to equip the flashlights.
content.html:
I remember about Jackal that its description.launch does not accept urdf models (i.e., flashlight and LED) from outside of the package. I think it is the same reason for Husky, but I will double-check it.

Maybe, there is another way to equip the flashlights.

content.html: I’m not superfamiliar with xacro but there’s some repetition in every flashlight. just wondering if it’s possible to move these blocks inside the xacro macro and use the parameters to avoid repetition.

Sample deployment of Husky/Jackal team into a cave environment

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/2224798273-pic.jpg)
‌

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/2295761883-Peek%202018-07-31%2011-45.gif)
‌

`husky_team.launch` and `jackal_team.launch` spawn teams of Huskies and Jackals respectively, in addition to one Iris quadcopter. The designs of the lights and dispositions are just for demonstration and to be redesigned.

**URDF**

* Added `urdf/xacro` files for flashlight and LED models \(in `subt_gazebo`\)
* Added `husky_equipments.urdf.xacro`, `jackal_equipments.urdf.xacro`, `iris_equipments.urdf.xacro` defining how a robot holds the lights
* Added revised versions of `husky.urdf.xacro` and `jackal.urdf.xacro`, so as to include the files above and to deploy multiple robots.

**Updated subt\_example\_node**

It has the following features now.

* Teleop: listens to topics advertised by joy stick/keyboard teleop
* Communication: uses CommsClient to send a message to another robot. Both sender and receivers flash their center LED.
* Flashlights: publishes ROS messages to control its flashlights.
* Control of a robot: publishes ROS message to each robot `cmd_vel` topic
* Selection: while being selected by the teleop, it blinks its left and right LEDs.

**Teleop by the keyboard**

Type:  
 `rosrun subt_example teleop_twist_keyboard.py`

It is almost the same as the original teleop script, but it displays a list of robots and you can choose a robot to control by hitting the corresponding number keys \(1-9 and 0\). The keys `a` and `s` turn the lights on and off, respectively. The script loads a yaml file `config/robot_config.yaml` containing a list of robot names. When you hit a number key while pressing down a shift key, the currently selected robot sends a message to the robot with the corresponding number.

**Teleop by the \(logitech\) joy stick**

Config data is in `config/logitech_config.yaml`

* To move robots: hold the left button \(LB\) and use the left joy stick to go forward/backward and turn.
* To use the turbo mode: hold the right button \(RB\) and use the same joy stick.
* For Iris, use the right joy stick to move vertically \(z-axis\) and horizontally \(y-axis\).
* To turn the lights on/off: use the left trigger \(LT\) / right trigger \(RT\).
* To select the robot: press A, B, X, or Y button \(the key bindings are defined in `config/robot_config.yaml`\).
* To send a message: press an arrow key

* Removed the sun

* Flashlights: publishes ROS messages to control its flashlights.
* Control of a robot: publishes ROS message to each robot `cmd_vel` topic
* Selection: while being selected by the teleop, it blinks its left and right LEDs.

**Teleop by the keyboard**

Type:  
 `rosrun subt_example teleop_twist_keyboard.py`

It is almost the same as the original teleop script, but it displays a list of robots and you can choose a robot to control by hitting the corresponding number keys \(1-9 and 0\). The keys `a` and `s` turn the lights on and off, respectively. The script loads a yaml file `config/robot_config.yaml` containing a list of robot names. When you hit a number key while pressing down a shift key, the currently selected robot sends a message to the robot with the corresponding number.

**Teleop by the \(logitech\) joy stick**

Config data is in `config/logitech_config.yaml`

* To move robots: hold the left button \(LB\) and use the left joy stick to go forward/backward and turn.
* To use the turbo mode: hold the right button \(RB\) and use the same joy stick.
* For Iris, use the right joy stick to move vertically \(z-axis\) and horizontally \(y-axis\).
* To turn the lights on/off: use the left trigger \(LT\) / right trigger \(RT\).
* To select the robot: press A, B, X, or Y button \(the key bindings are defined in `config/robot_config.yaml`\).
* To send a message: press an arrow key

**lava\_tube.world**

To make the environment to look more realistic \(and just for fun\)

* Removed the sun
* Added the color of the cave in model.sdf
update.title: Multiple Huskies/Jackals + Iris (in a dark lava tube)
